Here’s a simple, emoji-filled summary of the key Chemistry concepts from your SSC CHSL PDF1:

ðŸŒŒ Matter & Its States

  • Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space (except: heat, light, electricity, sound, magnetism, vacuum, shadow).
  • Particles of matter are tiny, have spaces between them, and are always moving (kinetic energy ðŸ’¨).
  • Intermolecular force: Strongest in solids ðŸ§±, weaker in liquids ðŸ’§, weakest in gases ðŸ’¨.

States of Matter

  • ðŸ§± Solid: Fixed shape & volume, particles packed tightly, not compressible.
  • ðŸ’§ Liquid: No fixed shape, fixed volume, particles move more freely.
  • ðŸ’¨ Gas: No fixed shape or volume, particles move freely, highly compressible.
  • ðŸŒŸ Plasma: Super-energized, ionized gas (found in stars, neon signs).
  • â„ï¸ Bose-Einstein Condensate: Super-cooled, low-density gas where atoms act as one quantum state.

ðŸ”¬ Atoms & Molecules

  • Atom: Smallest part of an element that can take part in a chemical reaction.
    • Example: Hydrogen atom is the smallest.
  • Atomic mass: Measured in atomic mass units (u), based on carbon-12.
  • Molecule: Group of two or more atoms bonded together (can be same or different elements).
  • Atomicity: Number of atoms in a molecule.
  • Ion: Charged particle.
    • Positive = Cation âž•
    • Negative = Anion âž–

âš–ï¸ Laws of Chemistry

  • Law of Conservation of Mass: Mass is neither created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction.
  • Law of Constant Proportions: Elements in a compound are always in fixed ratios by mass.

ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ”¬ Atomic Models

  • Daltonâ€™s Atomic Theory:
    • All matter is made of atoms.
    • Atoms can’t be created/destroyed.
    • Atoms of the same element are identical.
  • Thomsonâ€™s Model: “Plum pudding” â€“ electrons in a positive sphere.
  • Rutherfordâ€™s Model: Tiny nucleus (positive), electrons revolve around it.
  • Bohrâ€™s Model: Electrons in energy levels (shells: K, L, M, N…).

ðŸ§© Subatomic Particles

  • Electron (eâ»): Discovered by J.J. Thomson, negative charge.
  • Proton (pâº): Discovered by Goldstein, positive charge.
  • Neutron (nâ°): Discovered by Chadwick, neutral.

ðŸ§® Key Atomic Terms

  • Atomic Number (Z): Number of protons.
  • Mass Number (A): Protons + Neutrons.
  • Isotopes: Same atomic number, different mass (e.g., Hydrogen: Protium, Deuterium, Tritium).
  • Isobars: Same mass number, different atomic number (e.g., Argon-40 & Calcium-40).
  • Isotones: Same number of neutrons.

ðŸ§ª Chemical Formulae & Valency

  • Chemical formula: Shows which elements and how many atoms are in a compound.
  • Valency: Combining capacity of an element (number of electrons lost, gained, or shared).

ðŸ§¬ Molecular Mass & Avogadroâ€™s Number

  • Molecular mass: Sum of atomic masses in a molecule (e.g., Hâ‚‚O = 2Ã—1 + 16 = 18u).
  • Avogadroâ€™s constant: $6.022 \times 10^{23}$ (number of atoms in 12g of carbon-12).

ðŸ’¡ Fun Facts & Exceptions

  • Diffusion: Mixing of particles; fastest in gases, slowest in solids.
  • Rubber band: Can stretch (solid with flexibility).
  • Sponge: Solid but compressible due to air holes.
  • Plasma: Found in stars, neon lights.
  • BEC: Predicted by S.N. Bose & Einstein, at ultra-low temperatures.

ðŸ—ºï¸ Discovery & Geography

  • ðŸ›ï¸ Discovered: 1920-21 at Harappa (by D.R. Sahni) & Mohenjo Daro (by R.D. Banerjee)12.
  • ðŸŒ Spread: Over 1,250,000 sq km, covering parts of modern India & Pakistanâ€”much larger than Egypt or Mesopotamia13.
  • ðŸžï¸ Sites: 1,400+ settlements, including Mohenjo Daro, Harappa, Dholavira, Kalibangan, Lothal, Rakhigarhi, and more13.
  • ðŸžï¸ Location: Most settlements on river banks, especially the now-dry Saraswati river system1.

ðŸ™ï¸ Town Planning & Architecture

  • ðŸ§­ Grid Layout: Streets and buildings aligned east-west and north-south123.
  • ðŸ™ï¸ City Design: Well-planned cities with large gateways, citadels, and public buildings123.
  • ðŸ§± Materials: Mud bricks, kiln-fired bricks, wood, stone; bricks in 1:2:4 proportion12.
  • ðŸªŸ Houses: Private homes, large houses, and public structures; doors/windows faced side lanes for privacy1.
  • ðŸ›ï¸ Public Buildings: Great Bath at Mohenjo Daro (12x7m, 3m deep), granaries, and Lothalâ€™s dockyard for trade123.

ðŸš° Sanitation & Drainage

  • ðŸš¿ Advanced Drainage: Covered drains, bathing platforms, and latrines connected to main sewers123.
  • ðŸ§¹ Civic Sense: Even small towns had impressive sanitation systems12.

âš’ï¸ Crafts, Tools & Technology

  • ðŸ› ï¸ Bronze Age: Tools of copper, bronze, and stone; simple but effective (axes, chisels, knives, saws, etc.)123.
  • ðŸŽ¨ Artifacts: Seals (often with animals), pottery, jewelry, terracotta figurines, toys, and the famous bronze “Dancing Girl”123.
  • ðŸª™ Standardized Weights: Cubical/spherical weights made of chert, jasper, agate; used for trade (based on 16 and its multiples)14.
  • ðŸº Pottery: Wheel-made, painted with geometric and animal designs12.

ðŸš¢ Trade & Commerce

  • ðŸš¢ Trade Centers: Lothal had a dockyard; extensive internal and overseas trade with Mesopotamia and Egypt143.
  • ðŸ›¤ï¸ Transport: Bullock-carts, boats, and ships1.
  • ðŸ’Ž Imports: Copper (Rajasthan), stones (Sindh, Gujarat), lapis lazuli (Afghanistan), etc.1.

ðŸ“œ Script & Language

  • ðŸ“œ Script: 400â€“500 pictographic signs, still undeciphered1453.
  • ðŸ—£ï¸ Language: Possibly Dravidian or Indo-Aryan, but not confirmed13.

ðŸŒ¾ Agriculture & Food

  • ðŸŒ¾ Crops: Wheat, barley, rice, millets, peas, beans, cotton (worldâ€™s oldest evidence), sesame, mustard, dates152.
  • ðŸ„ Domesticated Animals: Sheep, goats, cattle, buffalo, elephants, camels, pigs, and possibly horses15.
  • ðŸ½ï¸ Diet: Included grains, milk products, vegetables, fruits, fish, and meat2.

ðŸ›• Religion & Beliefs

  • ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ¦° Mother Goddess: Terracotta figurines found in many homes123.
  • ðŸ§˜ Male Deity: Seals show a yogi-like figure (possibly Shiva as Pashupati)123.
  • ðŸŒ³ Nature Worship: Trees, animals, stones, and fire-altars123.
  • ðŸ§¿ Amulets & Charms: Used for protection; swastika symbol common12.
  • ðŸ§˜â€â™‚ï¸ Yoga: Figurines in yogic postures suggest yoga practice12.

ðŸ›ï¸ Society & Politics

  • ðŸ° Social Structure: Elite (citadel), middle class, and lower class (outside fortifications)1.
